ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was a virtual discussion before lab, and then afterwards anyone who wanted to could go to an optional in-person lab.

Professor Dawson modified lab protocols to allow safe, in-person labs whenever possible, but these were optional, and you could get by just as successfully in the course by attending the virtual pre-lab lectures and doing data analysis on the images/information he provided you.
Virtual lab with optional in-person component to complete some procedures.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned basic skills and techniques for genetic inquiry.

I learned how to work with different model organisms (bacteria, yeast, flies, plants). I also learned a lot about how different genetic conclusions could be inferred from different results, which really complemented the Genetics lecture course and helped me understand the concepts better. Finally, I was able to practice thinking critically about data and perform statistic analyses about our experiments

I was able to put some of the skills taught in the lecture to practice by doing recombination analysis on fly and plant datasets, and this actually solidified the concept more than when I learned it initially. Ultimately, I have a more solid understanding of how variation in yeast, flies, and Arabidopsis is analyzed.

Introduction to basic concepts in genetic techniques - understanding the role/importance of model organisms including drosophila, yeast and arabidopsis plants, PCR, DNA extraction, gene modifiers, recombination mapping, complementation tests, mutagenesis, etc

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
One of the strengths of the course was that each experiment often flowed into the next in some respect so you got a sense of how thorough genetic experimentation might work. 

A weakness was that canvas was vastly underutilized and instead, we received a deluge of emails that were often hard to parse with various bits of crucial course information. A weakness of the course was also a complete lack of transparency in terms of how our grade was determined or calculated. Each lab seemed to be graded on a rubric created post-facto. We also never received any of our quiz grade or worksheet grades back. He also added a quiz after telling us that we had already had our last quiz of the semester. The sum total of these actions is that I truly do not have any idea how I'm doing in the class (especially since he is curving the course despite there only being 15 students).

I liked how course is very structured and streamlined. Although it was confusing at times, performing steps from multiple labs in one class was very efficient. We could have had more time in between when a lab report was assigned and when it was due, because it was often a time crunch. I didn't like the quizzes, particularly because we never received feedback on them so we didn't know what to address in our lab reports.

A strength of the course was its content, the relationship between the lab exercises and subsequent lab reports, and the learning value of the reports themselves, but the later reports take very long because of the need to perform and document recombination analysis, Chi-squared tests, etc.

Super interesting material, great supplement to lecture course material. 

Weaknesses - TAs were not very accessible for questions/help with lab reports (which I recognize was partially due to the online format and not being able to see them in person, however a set schedule of office hours should have been set up each week, which did not happen), not exactly a weakness but lab reports took a veryyyy long time, and sometimes random quizzes and lab assignments were announced with very little notice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated how carefully the lab was set up for COVID safety. I liked working by myself, which would not be the case in normal years. This course might benefit from requiring in-person attendance. I wished we could have done everything that was originally in the lab, but sometimes sacrifices need to be made.
The independent analysis of data that Professor Dawson later collated for use in reports worked relatively well.

The virtual lecture before lab was quite helpful, and I appreciated that Prof Dawson sent us all the data we needed for the experiments whether or not we could go into lab ourselves. I also appreciated that in-person lab was optional because some students werent comfortable going in when there was a COVID outbreak on campus.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would take this course only if you need a bio lab and are willing to put in the work on lab reports. The class itself can be quite fun and the experiments are relatively elegant and straightforward. However, the obscure guidelines for written work necessitate a maximalist approach to the lab reports even if you have a clean understanding of the material.

I would recommend this course to another student. Not only do you gain experience with basic lab techniques, but taking the lab was very helpful in understanding the contents of the lecture course (that's like the opposite of most lecture-lab courses). Although the lab reports were a little long, they helped prepare me for writing actual scientific papers. This class should definitely be worth 1 credit though--you should be prepared to do some work, including pre-labs questions, prepping for quizzes, and the lab reports.
Yes, if you are interested in genetics and willing to/have the time to put in a lot of work on the lab reports. Definitely not a simple lab credit.
